title: Samson's Marriage and Riddle
shortSummary: Judges Chapter 14 recounts Samson's desire to marry a Philistine woman, an act that sets the stage for conflict with the Philistines who oppressed Israel. The chapter highlights Samson's supernatural strength, the famous riddle he poses at his wedding feast, and the ensuing betrayal that leads to violent retribution. This chapter reveals God's providential use of Samson's personal choices to challenge Israel's enemies.
timeline: c. 1100 BC - Period of the Judges, during Philistine oppression of Israel

keyCharacters.name: Samson
keyCharacters.description: A Nazirite judge of Israel known for his supernatural strength; in this chapter, he pursues a Philistine wife and demonstrates God's power through his feats.

keyCharacters.name: Samson's Wife
keyCharacters.description: A Philistine woman from Timnath whom Samson desires to marry; she plays a pivotal role in the riddle's revelation to the Philistines.

keyCharacters.name: Samson's Father and Mother
keyCharacters.description: Samson's parents who question his choice of a Philistine wife but unknowingly support God's plan through their actions.

keyCharacters.name: Philistine Companions
keyCharacters.description: Thirty men who attend Samson's wedding feast and attempt to solve his riddle, representing the Philistine opposition.

definitions.definition: A person consecrated to God by a special vow involving abstaining from wine, not cutting hair, and avoiding contact with the dead.
A dominant enemy people of Israel during the Judges period, often in conflict with the Israelites.
A puzzling question or statement posed for others to solve, often used here as a test of wisdom and cunning.
The empowering presence of God enabling Samson to perform extraordinary feats beyond natural human ability.

outline.heading: Samson's Desire for a Philistine Wife
outline.description: Samson visits Timnath, desires a Philistine woman as his wife, and despite his parents' objections, insists on marrying her. This decision is divinely purposed to begin conflict with the Philistines who oppressed Israel.

outline.heading: Samson's Encounter with the Lion
outline.description: On the way to Timnath, Samson kills a roaring lion by the Spirit of the LORD and later discovers honey in the lion's carcass, symbolizing God's provision and foreshadowing the riddle.

outline.heading: The Wedding Feast and the Riddle
outline.description: At his wedding feast, Samson poses a riddle to thirty Philistine companions, challenging them to solve it within seven days, with a wager of garments at stake.

outline.heading: Betrayal and Revelation of the Riddle
outline.description: Under threat, Samson's wife pressures him to reveal the riddle, which she then discloses to the Philistines, illustrating the dangers of misplaced trust and the consequences of disobedience.

outline.heading: Samson's Retribution and Aftermath
outline.description: Empowered again by the Spirit of the LORD, Samson kills thirty Philistines to pay his wager and returns home angry, while his wife is given to his companion, highlighting personal and communal conflict.

application: Trust God's providence even when His plans unfold through imperfect human decisions, as seen in Samson's marriage.
Guard the heart against compromising with ungodly influences that can lead to spiritual and relational harm.
Seek God's strength through the Holy Spirit to face challenges and opposition in life.
Be cautious in sharing sensitive information and remain faithful to God’s wisdom rather than yielding to pressure.

keyVerses.text: And the Spirit of the LORD came mightily upon him, and he rent him as he would have rent a kid, and he had nothing in his hand: but he told not his father or his mother what he had done.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the supernatural empowerment of Samson by God's Spirit, demonstrating divine enablement for His purposes.

keyVerses.text: And he said unto them, Out of the eater came forth meat, and out of the strong came forth sweetness.
keyVerses.significance: Samson’s riddle encapsulates the paradox of God's provision and strength, challenging the Philistines and revealing God's hand in Samson's life.

keyVerses.text: And the Spirit of the LORD came upon him, and he went down to Ashkelon, and slew thirty men of them, and took their spoil, and gave change of garments unto them which expounded the riddle. And his anger was kindled, and he went up to his father's house.
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows God's Spirit empowering Samson to execute judgment on Israel's enemies and the consequences of betrayal.
